data.title: 40 greatest music artists to come out of Ohio
data.meta_description: The best and most influential musicians who got their start in Akron, Cleveland, Columbus, Cincinnati and beyond.
data.text:
CLEVELAND, Ohio - Some often question Cleveland being labeled the birthplace of rock and roll.

The city has the history, centered on pioneering disc jockey Alan Freed, to back it up. But Ohio, in general, has a rich musical history that makes it one of the most important states when it comes to the evolution of sound in various genres.

Everything from shock rock and industrial metal to funk and R&B developed in the area. In listing the 40 greatest acts to come out of Ohio, we kept to artists that are known to have gotten their start in or are identified with the state.

Troy L. Smith, Cleveland.com

40 greatest music acts to come out of Ohio

From The O'Jays and Moonglows to Nine Inch Nails and Twenty One Pilots.

(Photo: The Plain Dealer)

Art Tatum

You may not have heard of Art Tatum, which is a shame since he’s considered one of, if not the greatest jazz pianist of all time. The Toledo native is a Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award winner, whose proficiency of technique went on to influence every pianist who came after him.

Essential Works: "Piano Starts Here," "The Tatum Group Masterpieces, Vol. 8," "The Art Tatum Solo Masterpieces, Vol. 1-8"

(Photo: ABC Records)

Bo Donaldson and The Heywoods

Bo Donaldson’s band formed in Cincinnati during the 1960s and spent its early years touring with The Osmonds before becoming an international sensation itself thanks to the hits “Billy Don’t Be a Hero” and “Who Do You Think You Are.” Both landed in the top 15 on the Billboard Hot 100.

Essential Works: "The Best of Bo Donaldson and The Heywoods"

(Photo: The Plain Dealer)

Bobby Womack

Cleveland native Womack first made a name for himself as a member of the Valentinos (Another big R&B act out of Northeast Ohio). He then moved on to a legendary solo career that would elevate the R&B genre. The Rock & Roll Hall of Famer's standards include "Across 100th Street," "If You Think You're Lonely Now" and "That's The Way I Feel About Cha."

Essential Works: "Fly Me to the Moon," "The Poet," "Bravest Man in the Universe

(Photo: Travis Shinn)

Bone Thugs-N-Harmony

Bone Thugs-N-Harmony put Cleveland on the hip-hop map during the 1990s after being discovered and mentored by Eazy-E. The group’s musical legacy still looms over the city’s rap culture to this day.

Essential Works: "Creepin on ah Come Up," "E. 1999 Eternal," "The Art of War"

(Photo: The Plain Dealer)

Bootsy Collins

Rock & Roll Hall of Famer Bootsy Collins is best known for his work with Parliament-Funkadelic. But prior to that, the Cincinnati native made a name for himself in and around Ohio in the funk project The Pacemakers, who would go on to become James Brown’s backing band.

Essential Works: "Stretchin' Out in Bootsy's Rubber Band," "Ahh…The Name is Bootsy, Baby!"

(Photo: Acrobat Licensing Ltd.)

'Bull Moose' Jackson

Some consider Cleveland native Bull Moose Jackson a pioneer of the dirty blues. The singer and saxophonist was a blue and R&B mainstay during the 1940s and remained the area until his death in 1989.

Essential Works: "The Bull Moose Jackson Collection"

(Photo: Anastasia Pantsios)

Chrissie Hynde

Akron native Hynde got into music while attending Kent State’s Art School and even joined a band with Mark Mothersbaugh of Devo. Of course, she’s best known for her evolution after moving out of Northeast Ohio, when she moved to Europe and formed The Pretenders.

Essential Works: "The Pretenders," "Learning to Crawl," "Stockholm"

(Photo: Carpark Records)

Cloud Nothings

Cleveland-bred Cloud Nothings has spend the 2010s as an indie darlings. The band’s first three albums on Carpark Records were critically acclaimed, with a third due out in early 2017.

Essential Works: "Attack on Memory," "Here and Nowhere Else"

(Photo: The Plain Dealer)

Dazz Band

Cleveland funk trio The Dazz Band is one of the few Northeast Ohio acts that can call itself a Grammy winner thanks to its 1982 hit “Let It Whip” on Motown Records.

Essential Works: "Let the Music Play," "Keep It Live"

(Photo: The Plain Dealer)

The Dead Boys

Formed out of the ashes of local band Rocket from the Tombs, The Dead Boys made a name for themselves in New York City as one of the pioneering punk bands of the era. The Dead Boys are credited with establishing the hardcore punk scene in the U.S. thanks to rowdy live performances.

Essential Works: "Young Loud and Snotty," "We Have Come for Your Children," "Night of the Living Dead Boys"

(Photo: Universal Studios/Pictures)

Dean Martin

Steubenville native Dean Martin was a jack-of-all-trades, excelling in everything from singing and comedy to acting and producing films. He’s one of the biggest icons in entertainment history, as a member of the Rat Pack and the man behind hits like “That’s Amore” and “You’re Nobody till Somebody Loves You.”

Essential Works: "Sleep Warm," "Dean Martin Sings," "Pretty Baby"

(Photo: Jules Bates)

Akron new wave art-punks Devo remain one of the biggest snubs when it comes to the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame, given the band’s expansive live performances, cult following and impact on the music video art form.

Essential Works: "On Moonlight Bay," "Lullaby of Broadway"

(Photo: The Plain Dealer)

Doris Day

Before becoming one of the biggest stars in Hollywood during the 1950s and 1960s, Cincinnati native Doris Day was a big band singer built a career that would go on to earn the Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award.

Essential Works: "On Moonlight Bay," "Lullaby of Broadway"

(Photo: The Plain Dealer)

Eric Carmen and the Raspberries

Cleveland’s Raspberries emerged during the 1970s as one of the first major acts in the power-pop genre. The band’s run was eventful, but short-lived. Singer Eric Carmen would go on to release several major solo hits, including “All by Myself,” “Hungry Eyes” and “Make Me Lose Control.”

Essential Works: "Raspberries," "Fresh Raspberries," "Eric Carmen"

(Photo: Myriam Santos)

Filter

There was life for Robert Patrick after Nine Inch Nails, as he was able to establish his own band Filter. The band’s single “Hey Man, Nice Shot,” became a huge alternative hit, while Filter has gone on to release seven studio albums.

Essential Works: "Title of Record," "Short Bus"

(Photo: The Plain Dealer)

Frankie Yankovic

One of the first national music stars to come out of Cleveland was Frankie Yankovic, a West Virginia native who was raised in Euclid, Ohio. Yankovic was known as “America’s Polka King.”

Essential Works: "Frankie Yankovic & His Yanks' Greatest Hits"

(Photo: The Plain Dealer)

Guided by Voices

Guided by Voices was a mainstay on the Dayton bar scene for years before readjusting its lineup and earning national acclaim for its fantastic live show and releasing mid-1990s classics like “Bee Thousand” and “Alien Lanes.”

Essential Works: "Propeller," "Bee Thousand," "Alien Lanes"

(Photo: The Plain Dealer)

James Gang

The James Gang proved its worth as one of the best rock bands in Ohio throughout the 1960s and 1970s with songs like “Funk #49” and “Walk Away.” The band is also known for the first major project for Joe Walsh, future member of the Eagles.

Essential Work: "Rides Again," "Greatest Hits"

(Photo: Lisa DeJong)

Jim Brickman

Cleveland-native Jim Brickman has become one of the most successful artists in adult contemporary music today with half a dozen gold/platinum albums.

Essential Works: "Peace," "The Disney Songbook," "Picture This"

(Photo: Jimmy Katz)

Joe Lovano

Grammy-winner and Cleveland native Joe Lovano has played with some of the best musicians in the world. He’s worked on a number of great albums as both a bandleader and a sideman, including “Quartets: Live at the Village Vanguard,” which earned “Jazz Album of the Year” from Down Beat magazine.

Essential Works: "From the Soul," "Quartets: Live at the Village Vanguard"

(Photo: Richard Shotwell)

John Legend

International singing sensation John Legend began his piano-playing career at a young age while attending school in Springfield, Ohio. His big break came when he played piano on Lauryn Hill on her hit “Everything Is Everything.” Since that time, Legend has won 10 Grammys (and an Oscar) for his stellar R&B recordings.

Essential Works: "Get Lifted," "Glory" (with Common)," "Once Again," "Wake Up!" (with The Roots)

(Photo: John Kuntz)

Kid Cudi

Right around the time Kanye West was paving the way for emo-rap, Kid Cudi was making his own mark on the genre with his “A Kid Named Cudi” mixtape. He would later score chart success with his “Man on the Moon” series and the hit “Day ‘n’ Nite.”

Essential Works: "Man on the Moon: The End of Day," "Man on the Moon: The Legend of Mr. Rager"

(Photo: The Plain Dealer)

LeVert

The Levert family has one of the richest musical histories in the state of Ohio, highlighted by Sean and Gerald (sons of the O’Jays’ Eddie Levert) and their R&B group LeVert. The three-piece released seven albums and a hit single in “Casanova” before Gerald launched a successful solo career.

Essential Works: "The Big Throwdown"

(Photo: Hell, etc.)

Marilyn Manson

While being one of the most controversial musicians of all time, Marilyn Manson was also a pioneer of the industrial rock genre, becoming an international superstar and a mainstay on MTV during the 1990s. He’s been nominated for four Grammys and sold millions of records worldwide.

Essential Works: "Antichrist Superstar," "Mechanical Animals"

(Photo: The Plain Dealer)

Michael Feinstein

Columbus native Michael Feinstein might not dominate the pop charts, but his work with the Great American Songbook has earned him international acclaim, including platinum albums and Grammy nominations.

Essential Works: "Big City Rhythms," "Romance on Film, Romance on Broadway," "The Sinatra Project"

(Photo: Joshua Gunter)

Michael Stanley

A regional superstar who earned national acclaim, Michael Stanley is still widely beloved in Northeast Ohio enough to play here at least a few times a year.

Essential Works: "Heartland," "Stagepass," "Right Back at Ya: 1971-1983"

(Photo: Megaforce)

2!&

Continuing the Ohio tradition of Industrial Metal, Cleveland’s Mushroom head has built a loyal fanbase that’s helped them sell millions of records worldwide.

Essential Works: "The Righteous & The Butterfly," "XIII"

(Photo: The Plain Dealer)

Nine Inch Nails

Ranked as one of the 100 greatest artists of all time by Rolling Stone, Nine Inch Nails became the face of a new genre when Trent Reznor helped pioneer industrial rock out of Cleveland. The band has been nominated for the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame twice, but has yet to get in.

Essential Works: "Pretty Hate Machine," "The Downward Spiral," "The Fragile"

(Photo: The Plain Dealer)

Ohio Players

The Ohio Players were one of the most influential and popular funk groups of the 1970s, thanks to big hits like “Love Rollercoaster,” “Fire” and “Funky Worm.” The group was one of the first acts inducted into the R&B Music Hall of Fame in 2013.

Essential Works: "Honey," "Skin Tight"

(Photo: The Plain Dealer)

Pere Ubu

Another major Cleveland rock act birthed from the ashes of Rocket from the Tombs, Pere Ubu may have gone on to be the most influential. The band’s avant-garde rock became a blueprint for future indie-rock acts.

Essential Works: "The Modern Dance," "Dub Housing," "Terminal Tower"

(Photo: The Plain Dealer)

Phil Keaggy and Glass Harp

Glass Harp was able to make a big enough name for itself in Northeast Ohio, earning opening slots on tours for Chicago, Yes, Alice Cooper and other big names. The band also evolved into more progressive territory throughout the 1970s, and remains semi-active to this day. Leader Phil Keaggy has also established himself as a solo act and guitar virtuoso, earning multiple Grammy nominations.

Essential Works: "Beyond Nature," "Crimson and Blue," "Glass Harp"

(Photo: Archives)

Screamin' Jay Hawkins

Cleveland native Screamin’ Jay Hawkins is mostly known for his landmark song “I Put a Spell on You.” But his pioneering of shock rock would go on to influence everyone from Alice Cooper and Marilyn Manson to Gwar and Black Veil Brides.

Essential Works: "I Put a Spell On You," "At Home With Screamin' Jay Hawkins"

(Photo: Warner Bros.)

The Black Keys

One of the biggest modern acts to come out of Ohio, Akron’s The Black Keys turned their humble beginnings in the area to international success. The duo has won seven Grammy Awards.

Essential Works: "Brothers," "El Camino"

(Photo: The Plain Dealer)

The Isley Brothers

If you would put this list in order of greatness, you could make a strong argument that The Isley Brothers should be at the top of the list. The group first earned acclaim with its massive hit “Should” in 1959, and has since released an endless number of classics, while influencing every R&B act to follow in the proceeding decades.

Essential Works: "3 + 3," "The Heat Is On," "Shout!" "Twist and Shout," "This Old Heart of Mine"

(Photo: RCA)

The Moonglows

One of the first Cleveland-native acts to score a No.1 hit on the R&B charts, The Moonglows made waves with “Sincerely” in 1954, a song co-written by Alan Freed. The group’s influential harmonies rightfully earned them induction into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame in 2000.

Essential Works: "The Best Of Bobby Lester and The Moonglows," "Look! It's The Moonglows"

(Photo: Keith Klenowski)

The National

Cincinnati’s The National has been earning rave reviews for its indie-rock music since the early 2000s, putting together one of the best catalogs of albums over the past decade and a half that has led to big festival headlining gigs.

Essential Works: "Boxer," "High Violet," "Alligator," "Trouble Will Find Me"

(Photo: The Plain Dealer)

The O'Jays

The O’Jays may have become an integral part of the Philadelphia soul movement. But, make no mistake, the act led by Eddie Levert originated in Canton. Before catching its big break in Philly, the group established itself with several early singles like “The Story of My Heart,” “How Does It Fell” and “Lonely Drifter.”

Essential Works: "Back Stabbers," "Ship Ahoy"

(Photo: Elektra)

Tracy Chapman

Few artists made such a major impact in such a short period of time as Cleveland native Tracy Chapman. The folk/blues standout became one of the most critically acclaimed artists in the world during the late 1980s with back to back releases of her self-titled debut and its platinum follow up “Crossroads.” She followed that up in the mid 1990s with her biggest single to date, “Give Me One Reason.”

Essential Works: "Tracy Chapman," "Crossroads"

(Photo: Atlantic Records)

Twenty One Pilots

Over just the past handful of years, Columbus’ Twenty One Pilots has gone from an upstart favorite of Alternative Press to one of the biggest rock bands in the world. The duo’s latest run includes three top-five hits on the Billboard Hot 100.

Essential Works: "Vessel," "Blurryface"

(Photo: Zapp Town Records)

ei

Ohio funk band Zapp has quite the musician tree, with the original lineup made up of the four Troutman brothers. The standout was Roger Troutman, who helped spearhead the funk movement, which was a building block for West Coast hip-hop. Zapp would also work closely with artists like George Clinton and Bootsy Collins.

Essential Works: "Zapp I," "Zapp II," "Zapp III"
